title: 114_s2681
content: The Act may be cited as the "San Juan County Settlement Implementation Act of 2016" and involves the exchange of coal preference right lease applications. The Act, known as the "San Juan County Settlement Implementation Act of 2016," allows the Secretary of the Interior to retire coal preference right lease applications with affirmative commercial quantities determination. The term "bidding right" refers to legal documentation used for coal lease sales under the Mineral Leasing Act. The Act allows the Secretary of the Interior to retire coal preference right lease applications by issuing bidding rights or making payments to the relevant State. Payments are sourced from funds that would otherwise go to the Treasury, and are treated as payments under the Mineral Leasing Act. The Leasing Act allows for the transferability of bidding rights issued under the Act, which must be notified to the Secretary. Bidding rights expire after a 5-year period, with the option to toll the period under certain circumstances. The Leasing Act allows for transferability of bidding rights under the Act, which expire after 5 years. Temporary injunctive relief or suspension of the Federal coal leasing program may be granted. SEC. 3. CERTAIN LAND SELECTIONS OF THE NAVAJO NATION. The Navajo Nation's land selections under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974 are canceled, and they are authorized to make new selections to replace the canceled lands, with some exclusions such as land within the National Landscape Conservation System and the Glade Run Recreation Area. The Navajo Nation's land selections under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974 are canceled, and they are authorized to make new selections to replace the canceled lands, excluding areas within the National Landscape Conservation System and specific critical environmental concern areas. Land subject to leases or contracts under certain acts is also excluded. The Navajo Nation's land selections under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974 are canceled, and they are authorized to make new selections to replace the canceled lands. The value of the land selected and the land subject to selections cancellation must be equal based on appraisals conducted according to specific standards. The Navajo Nation can make new land selections to replace canceled ones under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974. The selected land will be withdrawn from disposal, leasing, and development until placed into trust. The boundary of the Navajo Reservation is defined by a specific map. The Navajo Nation can designate new land selections to replace canceled ones under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974. The selected land will be withdrawn from disposal, leasing, and development until placed into trust. The boundary of the Navajo Reservation is defined by a specific map. SEC. 4. DESIGNATION OF AH-SHI-SLE-PAH WILDERNESS. The approximately 7,242 acres of land depicted on the map "San Juan County Wilderness Designations" dated April 2, 2015, is designated as the "Ah-shi-sle-pah Wilderness" under the Wilderness Act. The Wilderness will be managed by the Director of the Bureau of Land Management in accordance with the Wilderness Act, with adjustments for the date of enactment of this Act. The Wilderness Act does not create a protective perimeter around designated areas, allowing nonwilderness activities outside the boundary. Acquired land within the Wilderness becomes part of it and is managed according to the Wilderness Act. Grazing of livestock in the Wilderness is allowed to continue in accordance with the Wilderness Act and guidelines set forth in a specific report. Congress also addresses the release of Wilderness Study Areas for certain purposes. The Ah-shi-sle-pah Wilderness Study Area has been adequately studied for wilderness designation and is no longer subject to certain regulations. Expansion of Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness. Expansion of Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness by designating approximately 2,250 acres of Federal land as wilderness under the National Wilderness Preservation System. The designated land will be administered by the Director of the Bureau of Land Management in accordance with the Wilderness Act and the San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984. The San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984 does not create a protective perimeter around designated wilderness land. Nonwilderness activities outside the boundary are not precluded by activities within the designated wilderness. Acquired land within the boundary becomes part of the Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness. The designated land shall become part of the Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness and be managed according to the Wilderness Act, San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984, this section, and other applicable laws. Grazing of livestock in the wilderness area is allowed to continue based on specific guidelines.
